news politics spring-statement--what-rishi-"Budget : Key points from Chancellor Rishi Sunaks October announcementsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsRishi Sunak will deliver his Spring Statement  next Wednesday with grim news for millions of struggling families. Energy bills, National Insurance and inflation are all surging in April, outstripping benefit, pension and wage rises. Meanwhile tax and student loan repayment thresholds are being frozen in a squeeze on the cost of living. The Ukraine-Russia war will make inflation worse - and in a bombshell development, the Mirror understands Whitehall officials are braced for it to go higher than %. The SNP called for an emergency package of support while Labour demanded a windfall tax on oil giants. Boris Johnson said: “We’re taking steps to mitigate that to help people with the cost of living.” Yet Chancellor Rishi Sunak is understood to be strongly resisting bids to cut fuel duty, give more help for bills, or raise benefits or pensions by the same amount as inflation.So when and what is the Spring Statement, and what do we know about how it’s shaping up  Here’s what you need to know. When is the Spring Statement  Chancellor Rishi Sunak will deliver the  Spring Statement on Wednesday  March at .pm. He will give a speech in the Commons, followed by documents and forecasts published online. After complaints from the Speaker, less of his statement is expected to be ‘trailed’ in advance. But the Chancellor is set to appear on Sunday morning TV this weekend to give a preview. What is the Spring Statement The Spring Statement is a ‘mini-Budget’ by the Chancellor on the situation facing the economy.It is lower-key than a Budget and does not contain the same tax and spending powers.For instance, fuel duty and taxes on cigarettes and alcohol were already set for the year in October’s Budget. So was the minimum wage rise from £. to £. in April - though you can expect Mr Sunak to crow about it anyway.What will Chancellor Rishi Sunak announce during the Spring Statement The Chancellor is expected to lay out the sheer scale of the cost-of-living disaster hitting poor Brits. This will be in the form of Office for Budget Responsibilityforecasts on GDP growth, borrowing, debt and inflation. They will also have the warm-up acts of the Bank of England’s interest rates decision tomorrow, and monthly inflation figures for February - which will be published at am on the day of the Spring Statement. While growth is rising post-Covid, so is inflation - and it is set to be much worse than the last forecast . All this will ramp up pressure to announce extra help for households - but he’s reluctant to do that. Soaring inflation looks set to push up his borrowing bill, reducing the amount he claims he can spend. He could recycle already-announced policies or announce vague ‘consultations’ on future ones, but will it be enough  UK inflation could rise over % Shock analysis last week found inflation is set to peak at .% in April after the Ukraine invasion made it even worse.The Mirror understands Whitehall officials believe this figure, calculated by the Resolution Foundation, is broadly accurate. Officials in fact fear it could go even higher, beating the .% rate of  and even hitting %. This will blow October’s forecasts - that inflation would peak at .% this year and could rise to .% - out of the water. It will mean more expensive food and goods in the shops, hitting the poorest families hardest.Will there be help with energy bills Rishi Sunak is reluctant to offer extra help on energy bills - despite soaring prices and mounting pressure from MPs and charities. Previously he announced a £ council tax discount for Bands A-D next month, and a £ repayable rebate in October. Yet bills are rising by £ a year on April  and will rise again in October - possibly by another £, a year. This is a far bigger hit to the poorest tenth of households who spend around % of their income on energy. The richest spend %. Treasury officials want to wait until the run-up to the October rise before announcing more help. But a former Treasury minister told the Mirror that approach is “not going to work”, adding: “He’s going to have to do something, it just can’t be the full Covid.” Laura Suter, head of personal finance at AJ Bell, speculated that ministers might raise the £ repayable bills discount in October, or put back the start of repayments, currently April .But Mr Sunak has rejected Labour’s calls to cut VAT on energy bills or impose a windfall tax. Shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves said: Millions of people are worried sick about soaring bills. Meanwhile, BP have said theyaposve got more cash than they know what to do with, and have compared their record profits from inflated prices to a cash machine.” A long-term energy supply planBoris Johnson will set out a long-term energy supply plan for the UK to wean off Russian oilby the end of the year. This is expected to invest more in renewable power and nuclear power, as well as trying to get more oil from places like Saudi. But it’s not directly connected to the Spring Statement and could be published on a dferent day next week.Will benefits and pensions rise in April Despite gloom-laden inflation predictions, Mr Sunak will raise benefits by just .% - as little as £. a month on Universal Credit. In October he cut Universal Credit for millions by £ a week. Pensions will also rise by just .% after the triple lock was axed. These are both real-terms cuts that will leave the poorest struggling more.In a Budget rabbit out of the hat in October, he handed more generous benefits to .million working families by cutting the Universal Credit taper rate from p to p. But this only helps those who work, not the sick or out-of-work.The Resolution Foundation is worried there will be a “rollercoaster” with real benefits down this year and up next year. Tory MP Nigel Mills suggested bringing forward next yearaposs increase in Universal Credit to this autumn to solve the problem. The Mirror understands Mr Sunak is unlikely to raise benefits by more than .% because of the multi-billion pound cost - and the need to raise pensions and pay at the same timehe does. Will there be a pay rise for nurses, teachers and other public sector workers from April  Inflation means planned rises to public sector wages - due every April - will be wiped out by prices. Rising prices put huge pressure on the Chancellor to give these vital key workers pay rises above % or %, to avoid hitting them with a real-terms cut. But the Treasury is resisting such big cash rises. The government has spelt out plans to raise salaries for experienced teachers by only % in  .Health unions have also blasted plans to offer NHS staff in England a “miserly” % hike.Pressure on the Chancellor to reverse this will be huge but again, it will take a lot for him to budge. Will fuel duty be cut Fuel duty was already frozen at October’s Budget for a th year in a row - handing £, to the average car driver since . Despite environmental fears, Chancellor Rishi Sunak is being pressed to go even further and actually cut it. One idea from a Tory MP is to give a % cut to vital fuel users, such as haulage firms. But it’s understood the Chancellor resists this idea, because it would not make a huge dference to the overall cost of a tank. Not compared to the huge rises coming from inflation and the war in Ukraine, anyway.Will National Insurance and other tax rises be cancelled National Insurance will rise from % to .% from April . Tory MPs are still pushing for this to be cancelled as it’s a major tax rise just as a cost-of-living crisis hits. Downing Street say the rise is going ahead, despite previous claims Boris Johnson was wobbling. But some Tories still hold out hope. One said: “If itaposs about pride, they can now say that Ukraine is the reason they need to change course. Meanwhile more than  MPs have backed a bid from left-wing MP Richard Burgon to replace the hike with a wealth tax on the richest %. He says the same amount of income could be raised with a .% tax on wealth above £m. There are other tax squeezes - the Income Tax personal allowance and p rate threshold will freeze at £, and £,. And the VAT rate for hospitality firms, currently .% due to Covid, is due toto %. There are spaces here for the Chancellor to act but it would scupper his claims to be recovering from Covid.A vision beyond Covid and the war The Chancellor will likely try to set out a world beyond Covid but the Ukraine war and soaring inflation will make this dficult. Expect many references to infrastructure and ‘levelling-up’ but be on the lookout for old pots of money being reannounced. One Tory admitted to the Mirror: “The Rachel Reeves line that weaposre a high tax, low growth Government is true at the moment. “We donapost seem to have many pro-growth policies, weaposve pretty much given up on supply-side reforms. title: turning suspect saudi regime oil
story: Turning to suspect Saudi regime for oil to punish Putin shames Boris JohnsonBoris Johnson should not turn to the Saudi royal family to deal with the energy crisis - there are better ways than empowering these blood-soaked regimes, writes Maya Foa, director of legal action group ReprieveBy visiting Saudi Arabia, Johnson will confirm that the Kingdom will face no meaningful consequences for its mass execution Image: EPA SAUDI PRESS AGENCYopinionByMaya Foa:,  Mar |comments Tonight Boris Johnson is due to fly out to Saudi Arabia to meet Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman, so desperate for oil he is willing to pretend this week’s mass execution of  men there never happened.The damage to Britain’s moral standing on the global stage is huge, in a moment when this could not be more important.In an interview earlier this month, the Crown Prince swore he is modernising the Saudi justice system. Days later, he oversaw the largest mass execution in the country’s history. He is betting countries like the UK will look away, because they would rather fund his blood-soaked petro-state than Putin’s war machine. It is not an either or. There are better and more sustainable ways to deal with the energy crisis than empowering these regimes. By visiting Saudi Arabia, Johnson will confirm that the Kingdom will face no meaningful consequences for this mass execution. It virtually guarantees more people whose only crime was to protest against Bin Salman’s rule will be executed. People like Hassan al Maliki, an academic currently facing a death sentence for owning banned books.  The  executions at the weekend were probably beheadings, but Saudi ‘justice’ is such a black box we can’t be sure. The European Saudi Organisation for Human Rights, which tracks death sentences in Saudi Arabia, didn’t even know about  of the cases. These men were tried, convicted, sentenced and executed in complete secrecy.Of the  we do know about, at least three were tortured into making  confessions to terrorism offences after taking part in pro-democracy demonstrations. Aqil al-Faraj was held in solitary confinement, beaten all over his body and tortured with electricity and cigarette burns. He was imprisoned for five years, without access to a lawyer, before trial. This is the reality of Saudi capital punishment. The authorities label executed men ‘terrorists’ but there are political prisoners, non-violent drug offenders, and people arrested as children on death row. In , the UK and Saudi governments signed a top secret ‘Memorandum of Understanding’ on judicial co-operation. Since this agreement has been in place, the Saudi regime led by King Salman and his son has dramatically increased the pace of executions – there have been more than  in all. Ministers claim the UK is a restraining influence, but the Saudis don’t seem to have noticed.Visiting Riyadh so soon after this mass execution shames the Prime Minister and shames Britain. We must not show our revulsion for Vladimir Putin’s atrocities by rewarding those of Mohammed Bin Salman.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON King SalmanBoris JohnsonVladimir PutinTerrorismHuman rightsPoliticsRussia Ukraine warDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: universal credit claimants winter debt
story: A third of Universal Credit claimants skipped meals this winter - and itll get worseResearch published today sets out how benefit recipients got into debt, visited foodbanks and went without meals as they struggled over the past few monthsSome UC recipients turned to foodbanks over the winter Image: Adam Gerrard   Daily MirrorByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Mar |commentsA third of Universal Credit claimants went a day with only one meal or without eating at all over the winter, a study reveals today. A YouGov poll of , UC recipients for the Trussell Trust foodbank network found two in five people were forced into debt just to eat and pay bills. With more than . million people claiming the benefit, it suggests .m could have skipped food or only eaten once in  hours. Some % of those on the Government’s flagship welfare payment needed to visit a foodbank at least once since the start of December. Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter The research comes as the charity braces for a fresh surge in demand next month when the energy price rise hits, National Insurance hike bites and council tax rises.  Trussell Trust chief executive Emma Revie said: “Right now, the cost of living is forcing hundreds of thousands of families across the country into a downward spiral of debt just to get by. “People are telling us theyaposre going days with minimal food, are having to endure the cold to save money and are being forced to turn to foodbanks with devastating effects on people’s mental health. “Social security should be protecting people from debt and foodbanks, not pushing them towards it.”  Inflation is running at .% and is tipped to leap further when latest figures are revealed. Experts believe it could hit % - yet benefits are due to rise by just .% from April , meaning claimants will suffer big real-terms cuts. Ms Revie urged the Government to hike benefits by at least the current inflation level when Chancellor Rishi Sunak delivers his Spring Statement mini-Budget on Wednesday. She said: “We are calling on the UK Government to bring benefits in line with the forecast rate of inflation as a bare minimum in the upcoming Spring Statement, to prevent thousands more people being forced into debt and through the doors of foodbanks. “Longer term, it is vital we strengthen our social security system so it protects us all from harm and invest in local crisis support so no one needs to use a foodbank to get by.”  Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: Twelve years of Tory economic failure has landed families with a devastating cost of living crisis of rocketing energy bills, price rises, punishing tax increase and the second severe cut to Universal Credit within six months. “It means people - often in work - turning to foodbanks and weighed down with crushing debts. “In recent weeks Iaposve heard from families at foodbanks of the impossible choices they are making between heating and eating with, for example, one woman saying she canapost afford to keep the electricity bills to keep her fridge on.  The coming increase to NICs must be halted and ministers should impose a one-off windfall tax on oil and gas producers to bring down energy bills for families struggling to get by. A Government spokesman said: “We recognise the pressures people are facing with the cost of living, which is why we’re providing support worth £billion this financial year and next to help.  “This includes putting an average of £, more per year into the pockets of working families via changes to Universal Credit, freezing fuel duties to keep costs down and helping households with their energy bills through our £.bn Energy Bills Rebate. “We’re also boosting the minimum wage by more than £, a year for full-time workers and our £million Household Support Fund is helping the most vulnerable with essential costs.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON YougovTrussell TrustSpring StatementJonathan AshworthTaxCouncil taxEnergy billsMinimum wagePrice risesSave moneyPoliticsDebtFood banksInflationBenefitsUniversal Credit" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: who mp tulip siddiq nazanin
story: Who is MP Tulip Siddiq as Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe is finally free toto UK The Labour MP for Hampstead and Kilburn has worked tirelessly on behalf of Nazanin, who is her constituent, to try and secure her release.ByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsLabour MP Tulip Siddiq was briefly applauded in the Commons this afternoon as she thanked MPs who campaigned to help secure Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe’s release.While applause is not allowed in the Commons chamber, a number of claps were heard as the Labour MP for Hampstead and Kilburn finished her speech hours before Nazanin is reunited with her family.The Labour MP has worked tirelessly to secure Ms Zaghari-Ratclfeaposs release, working with her constituent and Nazaninaposs husband, Richard Ratclfe.Minutes after it was confirmed Nazanin will be coming home, Ms Siddiq said on Twitter : “Nazanin is at the airport in Tehran and on her way home.“I came into politics to make a dference, and right now I’m feeling like I have.” We look into Ms Siddiqaposs le...  Who is Tulip Siddiq Tulip Siddiq has supported the Labour Party since she was  years old, first She comes from an extremely political background her grandfather is the founding father and first president of Bangladesh, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.Her auntie Sheikh Hasina is currently the prime minister of Bangladesh.Ms Siddiq’s politics is driven by her mum and auntie’s struggle to seek safety in the UK and the care her disabled father received from the NHS.The Labour MP’s grandfather was assassinated by Bangladesh soldiers In  alongside  members of his family. Her mum and want survived as they were in Germany at the time, but lately claimed political asylum in the UK. Ms Siddiq’s dad suffered a stroke which left him in a wheelchair and unable to speak for five years. During her election campaign, speaking to the Evening Standard, she said: “I joined the Labour Party because of the NHS my father received really good treatment here.”  She has worked for Amnesty International, commenting on the trafficking of women, the Greater London Authority, Save the Children and Brunswick where she worked on corporate social responsibilities. The -year-old from Sutton, London, first won her Hampstead and Kilburn seat with a huge voter turnout of .% in . In her first address to the Commons she praised Britain for being a save haven to refugees and asylum seekers. My constituency elected the daughter of a political asylum seeker. Nineteen members of her family had been assassinated at home. My mother came to Britain because this [the UK] was a safe haven for her. And what my mother’s story tells you is that immigration is not simply an economic phenomenon. Britain has been seen for many years as a safe haven for political freedom and we must not slip away. What was Tulip Siddiq’s involvement with Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe’s case  Ms Siddiq has campaigned tirelessly on behalf of her constituents Nazanin and Richard Ratclfe. As their MP, she appeared at a number of press events with Richard, raised eight urgent questions and took part in dozens of events to ensure Nazaninaposs case was heard. Speaking in the Commons hours after Nazaninaposs release was confirmed, Ms Siddiq said: I want to pay tribute to my constituent Richard Ratclfe for his relentless campaigning, but I also think he’s really set the bar high for all husbands. “Can I say to Nazanin, welcome home, after six long years. And can I say to Gabriella , this time mummy really is coming home.”  She later added: Can I thank all the MPs on behalf of Richard Ratclfe who texted me just before I stood up, to say thank you across the chamber. Because whichever side of the House you were in, you worked hard, everyone worked hard, to make sure that Nazanin was released.”Foreign Secretary Liz Truss thanked Ms Siddiq for her campaigning.Ms Truss also told MPs: It was only when we heard that the wheels were up in Tehran that we really knew it was happening. I was just extremely concerned to make sure that Nazanin and Anoosheh had really been able to leave Iran, and I’m so delighted that we are going to be able to welcome them home today, and the family is going to be able to welcome them home today. Sadly there are still two other Brit nationals that have not had the same amount of attention in the Commons, and are still being held hostage in Iran. Morad Tahbaz has been released but on furlough. Mehran Raoof is still being held hostage. title: bees wasps nesting speed gauges
story: Exclusive: Flight delays at Heathrow Airport blamed on bees and wasps nesting in planesA BA Airbus A- abandoned take-off after the captain’s speed reading showed as less than the co-pilot’s. An inspection found the pitot probe was blocked with a solid soil-type materialThe insects got into planes run by BA and Virgin when flights were reduced in the pandemic Image: Getty ImagesByAndrew Buckwell:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Planes from Heathrow have been stopped from taking off by bees and wasps nesting in vital speed gauges. The insects got into planes run by BA and Virgin when flights were reduced in the pandemic, the Air Accidents Investigation Branch found after a probe into three incidents at the airport last June.A BA Airbus A- abandoned take-off after the captain’s speed reading showed as less than the co-pilot’s. An inspection found the pitot probe was blocked with a “solid soil-type material”. The next day a BA A parked in a bay nearby had a series of error messages on its flight display, caused by similar blockages, and the problem also forced a BA  to abandon take-off. The AAIB found eight planes in all were affected and sent samples to the Natural History Museum for analysis.  Wall mason wasps were found incubating in a BA Airbus  and there was an infestation of the hairy-toothed small leafcutter bee in a Virgin Airbus A The AAIB report said insect blockages were “not a new hazard, but one likely exacerbated due to the unusually low operational tempo in the pandemic”. story: First thing Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe wants when she gets home is a cup of teaNazanin, , said she is looking forward to a British brew made by her husband Richard Ratclfe when she finally s to their London homeBritish mum Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe is on her way home after six years in an Iranian prison Image: PAByPatrick DalyLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has told her husband the first thing she wants is for him to make her a cup of tea when she gets back to Britain after being held captive in Iran for six years.Richard Ratclfe said his we would probably be directing tidying-up at their home in north-west London but that the family first planned to find some solace where for a few days.He said there was huge relief that his we was on the journey back to the UK, where he hoped they could embark on a new le together.Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe, , was detained on security charges by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard at Imam Khomeini airport in  after a holiday visit to Iran where she introduced her daughter Gabriella to her parents.  On Wednesday, it was announced she had been freed after the UK Government settled a £ million debt relating to a military deal in the s. Mr Ratclfe said he hoped the homecoming would allow them to stop being a moment in history and become a normal family again. Speaking to broadcasters alongside seven-year-old Gabriella outside their home in the capital, he said: There will probably be a couple of days of peace and quiet somewhere , and then back here.The first thing she wanted was for me to make her a cup of tea, so we will do. I think actually we were looking at the house and it needs a bit of tidying, so there might be a bit of tidying, perhaps directed by mummy when she comes back. Mr Ratclfe, who has twice been on hunger strike while campaigning for his weaposs , said there would be bumps as she adjusts to her surroundings.  There is a recovery process. You canapost get back the time that is gone, thataposs a fact, he said in response to being asked about how the family planned to make up for the six years apart. But we live in the future and not the past, so weaposll take it one day at a time. He continued: I think it is going to be the beginning of a new le, a normal le, and hopefully a happy family.  And there will be bumps, no doubt, and all the normal squabbles we had before but, yeah, I think weaposre really looking forward to seeing her. Mr Ratclfe described his we as pretty agitated in the run-up to getting on a plane out of Iran but said she had been grinning since boarding the plane, on which she is headed to the Gulf state of Oman before travelling on a second flight to Britain. story: Greggs fan confused and deflated after buying beef and veg pasty with no fillingPaul, a regular at Greggs in Hull, bought his usual - a beef and vegetable pasty - but says he was left feeling "confused and deflated" when the lighter-than-usual and oddly shaped snack was completely devoid of fillingThe beef and vegetable pasty was completely hollow Image: Supplied pictureByHarry InghamRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A Greggs regular was left feeling confused and deflated after realising his snack was just a shell without its tasty beef and vegetable filling.Paul went to Greggs in Hull for his usual, a beef and vegetable pasty, only to find it felt unusually light.He also wonderedsomething was wrong with his food because of its odd shape, Hull Live reports.Paul took a bite but soon realised his snack was nothing but a shell - a very disappointing shell. Though he was less than impressed, Paul didnapost have time toto the store to lodge a complaint - and ended up having to skip lunch. Speaking to Hull Live about the ordeal, Paul said: When I received the pasty I saw it was an unusual shape and I thought, aposthis is strangeapos. On my way back to work, I bit into it and realised that it had no filling in it at all. I was quite deflated. I paid £. for a shell - a very disappointing shell.  I showed my friends and they all laughed at me. I was quite annoyed in the end as I didnapost have time to go back, so I ended up without any lunch. You just wonder, aposhow did that get out on the shelf apos Paul said: Iaposll still go back to Greggs because itaposs my favourite, but Iaposll have to check the weight of my pasty next time before I leave. They can trick me once, but they wonapost trick me twice! A Greggs spokesperson said: “Oh crumbs! We certainly didn’t intend for our Beef and Vegetable Pasty to be given to this customer without the tasty filling. “We’d love the customer to get in touch with us through our customer care team so we can put it right for them.  Just weeks ago, a similar incident sparked fury from chocolate fans. Angry KitKat customers sank their teeth into the confectionary classic only to find no wafer inside - just a solid choc bar. KitKats are traditionally a chocolate-coated biscuit bar with three layers of wafer biscuit inside. But it is not just the original bar showing up waferless - the brandaposs aposChunkyapos and flavoured ranges are too. One angry chocoholic Bronwyn Openshaw said: Iaposm actually quite upset because it doesnapost taste nice without the wafer. Tracy Bennett was equally unhappy and fumed: If I didnapost want wafer, I wouldnapost have bought a KitKat. Not happy. Yvonne Donnelly added: Gutted I got a KitKat with no wafers inside, just orange chocolate. Bels Reed even joked that the lack of wafer made her manager cry. Yet Logan Bradley bucked the trend and said: I just bit into a Kit Kat that didnapost have a wafer in it and honestly it made my whole day. title: heads must roll over horrific
story: Heads must roll over horric strip-search of Black teenage schoolgirlEva Simpson on the shocking news involving a -year-old teenager who was stripped-searched over concerns at school that she was in possession of cannabisThe police have apologised Image: Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar  No s, no buts. Everyone involved in the strip search of a -year-old black schoolgirl needs to be sacked – immediately.That includes politan Police officers who carried out this utterly inappropriate act, and the staff at the school who called them in the first place and allowed this to happen. None of them should be in a position of authority over anyone, let alone children, again. The child was suspected of carrying cannabis. Let’s be clear, she wasn’t seen smoking or even in possession of the drug. Her “crime”, as far as the school and the police were concerned, was to allegedly smell of it. And that was enough for the full force of the law to descend on her.  Instead of calling her parents or another appropriate adult, the staff rang the police. The child was taken to the medical room of the school in Hackney, East London, and stripped-searched by two female officers while the teachers waited outside. The details of the intimate search are too graphic to go into. The girl was on her period and during the ordeal she was forced to take off her sanitary pad as officers searched for drugs. They didn’t find any. A child safeguarding review concluded this week the incident was unjustied and racism was “likely” to have been a factor. The review found it was highly likely there was “adultication bias”, where adults see black children as being older than they are and don’t treat them in age-appropriate ways. As a mother, and a mother of black children, it breaks my heart to think what this poor young girl went through. You’d think this type of treatment is reserved for terrorist suspects or highly dangerous criminals, not a child at school. She was treated this way because she is black. Her parents have spoken of the profound impact this ordeal has had on their daughter. She went from being “happy-go-lucky to a timid recluse”. Time and time again we see public authorities fail black children. And then they wonder why black communities have so little faith in them. The police have apologised. Standard procedure which means nothing. And the incident is being investigated by the Independent Office for Police Conduct. What we really need is action, to see heads roll and compensation for the girl and her family. I hope the young victim is getting all the support and care she needs to heal and live le to the full. She shouldn’t suffer for something that wasn’t her fault. If she does, that will be an even bigger failure. title: little known highway code rule
story: Little-known Highway Code rule can knock £ off drivers petrol billA Highway Code rule that is little known amongst motorists could save people as much as £ in fuel costs at a time when prices at the pump are spiking in the cost of living crisisA Highway Code rule could save drivers hundreds of pounds Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByJames RodgerRegional Content EditorTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsBrits could use a little known rule to cut their petrol bills by as much as £, as the cost of living crisis deepens, and itaposs even advised in the Highway Code.Petrol prices have been soaring with inflation in recent months and now sanctions on Russia as a result of the Ukraine invasion is also having an impact. But by simply switching off the engine while waiting in queues motorists could save hundreds of pounds, reported BirminghamLive. Motoring experts have said that cutting the engine while stationary could mean drivers end up spending £ less on petrol per year - and it is recommended by the Highway Code. By using this simple trick where the ignition is switched off as well, motorists will also be doing less damage to the environment.  The advice comes as drivers continue to be clobbered by record fuel prices as petrol reaches an average of £. per litre. MotorEasy founder and CEO Duncan McClure Fisher said: “One thing many people do that is entirely unnecessary is to leave their engine idling. This can be done first thing in the morning to ‘warm it up’ or when stuck in traffic. Even dropping off something at a friend’s house can see people leave the motor running instead of turning off the ignition. “While this might seem very innocent, research has shown an idling engine can burn through three to four pence of fuel a minute.  If you are doing  minutes of warming up, five days a week, and spending another  minutes per week stuck in traffic – that adds up to a very handy £ a year that’s being wasted.” Figures from data firm Experian Catalist show the average cost of a litre of petrol at UK forecourts has increased by  pence in the past month. RAC fuel spokesman Simon Williams said: With the spring statement just a week away, drivers will be looking to the chancellor to end their misery by cutting duty or VAT. One thingaposs for sure: simply reiterating that fuel duty has been frozen at  pence a litre simply isnapost going to cut it. title: miracle twins born 22 weeks
story: Miracle twins born at  weeks with no chance of survival finally go homeBrother and sister Harley and Harry were born at just  weeks after doctors warned their worried parents they had virtually no chance of surviving- but have now gone homeHarley and Harry have defied the odds and have left hospitalByAntony ThrowerNews ReporterKate Lally:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMiracle twins given a zero per cent chance of surviving their birth have headed home from hospital with their delighted parents. Harley and Harry were conceived through IVF and were born at just  weeks and five days.Parents Jade and Steve Crane had been warned by doctors it could be a miscarriage as the tiny tots were so young, telling them to “prepare to say goodbye”.But when they were born they showed signs of le so the team burst into action.Now, after  days of intensive care, the brother and sister have been allowed to go home, the Liverpool Echo reports.Former mental health nurse Jade said: Iaposm so proud of my babies - theyaposre little fighters. “Theyaposre doing absolutely amazing. Theyaposre doing all the things that we were told they wouldnapost do - theyaposre crying, theyaposre surviving.  The doctors were saying the babies wouldnapost survive at this gestation. I was still two weeks away from what the UK classes as viable and the babies were given a zero per cent chance of survival. “It was only because I was at a teaching hospital and that the babies were born with signs of le that they chose to intervene medically.”The couple underwent eight cycles of IVF over  years as they tried to start their family, tragically suffering three miscarriages and an ectopic pregnancy before the twins’ arrival.Jade discovered she had an overactive immune system, causing her body to reject the pregnancies before the couple moved from a fertility clinic in Nottingham to one on Harley Street in London.Jade was prescribed several types of medication in order to combat her immune system problems. Jade added: On our eighth cycle of IVF, we had two embryos transferred which both worked and we ended up with boy and girl twins. “I couldnapost let myself believe it, I was so fearful of a miscarriage or something going wrong. I was still in disbelief when we got to  weeks, and I hadnapost even hit my third trimester when I went into labour so we hadnapost bought anything. “The few bits of clothes that I did buy made me think that I better keep the tags on just in case - you just donapost want to let yourself believe. The couple checked in at Queens Medical Hospital in Nottingham on October  when Jade leaked fluid at home for several days at  weeks.  The babies were not considered to be viable and the poor mum believed she would lose her precious twins. She added: The doctor kept saying it was a miscarriage but I said it couldnapost be because I could feel the babies moving. I knew they were ok but was being told they wouldnapost survive at this gestation. It was only because the babies were born with signs of le that they chose to intervene medically. They were alive, moving around, and they cried. Their little cries sounded like a tiny kitten.” The tiny children were finally allowed home on Monday- just two weeks after their initial due date. Steve added: The absolutely stunning doctors, nurses and surgeons have all been part of the making of this moment. “Itaposs hard to say goodbye to them but I hope I never see them again. title: nazanin zaghari ratcliffe beams finally
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe beams as she finally boards plane to UK - and shes wearing Ukraine coloursBritish-Iranian mum-of-one Nazanin, who had her passport ed yesterday after six years in a "hell hole" prison outside of Tehran, Iran, will be reunited with her daughter and husband later tonightJailed Brit Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe is seen smiling from ear to ear as she sits on the plane that willher home to the UKByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Jailed Brit Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe can be seen beaming and dressed in the colours of the Ukraine flag as she sits on the plane that willher home to the UK after six long years in an Iranian jail. The British-Iranian mum-of-one, who had her passport ed yesterday after six years in a hell hole prison outside of Tehran, will be reunited with her daughter and husband later tonight.She can be seen with a massive smile, a yellow dress and a blue headscarf draped around her shoulders while sitting on the UK-charter flight that is expected to land at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire. Her local MP Tulip Siddiq tweeted: Nazanin’s plane took off from Oman just over half an hour ago and she’s due to arrive in the UK this evening. Here she is on the plane - the final step in what has been a six year long ordeal. The -year-old was initially taken to Oman, the Gulf state reportedly involved in behind-the-scenes negotiations to secure her release.Her husband Richard Ratclfe said he was “deeply grateful” for her release and that he and their daughter Gabriella were “looking forward to a new le”. Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe has been detained in the Middle East for nearly six years after being arrested while taking her daughter to see her family. She was accused of plotting to overthrow the Iranian government, which she denied. Labouraposs Tulip Siddiq, the familyaposs local MP, confirmed the news in tweet: Nazanin is at the airport in Tehran and on her way home. I came into politics to make a dference, and right now I’m feeling like I have.  Siddiq earlier said she had been told from husband Richard Ratclfe that Nazanin is at the airport in Tehran but “still under the authority of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard”. He told her “they can smell freedom, they just haven’t grasped it yet” The familyaposs lawyer Hojjat Kermani said she had been freed alongside Anousheh Ashoori, following talks between London and Tehran over a £million debt between the UK and Iranian governments. Both of them are on their way to the airport in Tehran to leave Iran, Kermani said.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said: I can confirm Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe and Anoosheh Ashoori willto the UK today, and Morad Tahbaz has been released from prison on furlough. They will be reunited with their families later today.A statement from Truss continued: Their release is the result of years of hard work and dedication by our brilliant diplomats, and intensive efforts over the past six months. I pay tribute to my predecessors and the Prime Minister, who have all worked hard to resolve this issue. We have the deepest admiration for the resolve, courage and determination Nazanin, Anoosheh and Morad, and their families, have shown. They have faced hardship that no family should ever experience and this is a moment of great relief. In parallel, we have also settled the IMS debt, as we said we would. title: nazanin zaghari ratcliffes spirit never
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfes spirit never faltered despite all the adversitiesIt is hard to comprehend the torment Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has endured since she was arrested on trumped-up charges by the Iranian authorities - but she can now be reunited with her familyNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe with her husband Richard Ratclfe when their daughter Gabriella was a baby Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Mar |comments For six years Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has dreamed of being freed from her Iranian jail and reunited with her family.That moment has now come true. It is hard to comprehend the torment she has endured since she was arrested on trumped-up charges by the Iranian authorities. Twice she went on hunger strike. Her health suffered. She lost two appeals and had her sentenced increased. Many would have been broken by this adversity but Nazanin’s spirit never faltered. It was matched only by the love, tenacity and dedication of her husband Richard who campaigned tirelessly for her release. They did not deserve to be the pawns in a diplomatic power game between London and Tehran. Nor did they deserve to be let down by Boris Johnson whose blundering prompted Iran to level fresh charges against her. This story was not destined to have a happy ending. The fact that it does is a testament to their resilience and devotion to each other.  No more delays Vladimir Putin’s brutal invasion has created the worst humanitarian disaster in Europe since the Second World War. Almost three million Ukrainians have been forced to leave their homes as they seek sanctuary from the Russian bombardment. That number is set to rise as more people flee the besieged cities in Eastern Ukraine. They are in desperate need of food, clothes and a place to live. The tens of thousands of people who have signed up to the Homes for Ukraine scheme shows that households across Britain are ready to help. The only thing standing in their way is the Government’s delay in carrying out checks. Now is the time for compassion, not cold-hearted box ticking and foot dragging. story: Timeline of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfes detention in Iran as she finally s homeNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe was detained by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard at Tehran airport after visiting Iran to introduce her daughter Gabriella to her parents in Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe on a plane on her way back to the UK Image: via REUTERSByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe was detained in Iran for nearly six years after being arrested while taking her daughter to see her family.She was accused of plotting to overthrow the Iranian government, which she denied.Labouraposs Tulip Siddiq, the familyaposs local MP, tweeted an image of Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe this afternoon, wearing a yellow top and a grey scarf, smiling on the window seat of a plane.Itaposs been  long years - and I canapost believe I can FINALLY share this photo, Ms Siddiq wrote. Nazanin is now in the air flying away from  years of hell in Iran. My heart goes out to Gabriella and Richard, as her long journey back home to them gets closer by the minute. #NazaninIsFree  Hereaposs a timeline of Nazaninaposs detention in Iran.April Nazanin is detained by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard at Tehran airport after visiting Iran to introduce her daughter Gabriella to her parents. September  Richard Ratclfe says his we has been jailed for five years following a conviction on unspecied “national security-related” offences. November  Boris Johnson tells MPs that Nazanin was working in Tehran training journalists at the time of her arrest. Four days later, she was summoned before an unscheduled court hearing, where his comments were cited as proof that she was engaged in “propaganda against the regime”.A Foreign Office spokesman says Mr Johnson accepted he “could have been clearer”. November  Ratclfe says his we has seen a medical specialist after finding lumps on her breasts and is “on the verge of a nervous breakdown”. May  Ratclfe says his we has been told to expect another conviction after appearing in court over a new “invented” charge. August  Nazanin is given temporary release from prison for three days and her husband says it feels like “home is one step closer”. She s to prison three days later. October  The couple’s daughter Gabriella s to the UK after more than three years living with her maternal grandparents in Tehran.  January  Richard Ratclfe and their then five-year-old daughter Gabriella meet the PM in Downing Street, but Ratclfe says there was “no breakthrough”. March  Nazanin is temporarily freed from jail due to the Covid pandemic and can only go within  metres of her parents’ home. The family are able to talk via video calls for several hours a day. March  On the day Nazanin’s sentence is due to come to an end, her MP reveals she has faces a new court date. The following month she is given another one-year jail term and banned from leaving Iran for a year. May  Iranian state TV claims Britain will pay the £ million debt relating to a cancelled order for , Chieftain tanks dating back to the s, paving the way for Nazanin’s release. November  Ratclfe ends a -day hunger strike outside the Foreign Office. March  Nazanin’s MP says her constituent has had her British passport ed and a team of officials are in Tehran to negotiate. Hours later Tulip Siddiq announces that she is at Tehran airport and on her way home. story: Woman, , diagnosed rare, incurable disease fears it will kill her at any momentAbbey Parker, from Willington, Derby, left doctors stumped when she visited them complaining of pains in her arm, chest and kidneys, only to find out she had an incurable diseaseAbbey Parker, from Derby, was diagnosed with Behcets after complaining to doctors she had a pain in her arm Image: Abbey ParkerByFaith PringJenny MoodySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA teaching assistant who was diagnosed with a rare and incurable disease after she went to the doctors complaining of arm pains fears it will kill her at any moment.Abbey Parker, from Willington, Derby, was diagnosed with Behcetaposs disease - a condition which inflames blood vessels and tissues - after she began getting pains in her arms, chest and kidneys.The -year-old left doctors stumped medics when she visited the Royal Derby hospital in November last year, only to be diagnosed with heart weakness after multiple tests.She received the shocking news from Dr Robert Berg who she has since thanked for saving her le, Derbyshire Live reports. Speaking about her experience, Abbey said: I got admitted for the kidney infection because I needed an intravenous drip and they kept me in for some more tests. But on one of the rounds of testing there was a bit of miscommunication - but it worked in my favour. The doctors asked meit hurt anywhere and I said it hurt to breathe, but I was referring to my kidney - he thought I meant my chest. They sent for further CT scans on my chest and found the aneurysmon my heart. I was there for  days, my mouth was full of ulcers and I had a lump under my armpit, which turned out to be an aneurysm as well.  Itaposs such a rare disease, normally no one would think about it being that. It was my second kidney infection in such a short period of time so I think that was a bit of a red flag. Boyfriend Jack Bates, , admitted he thinks without the shock diagnosis his girlfriend wouldnapost have made it to Christmas. The electrician has since decided to raise money for Dr Bergaposs research department with a three peaks challenge. He added: Her condition is a lot to take in some days, having to take some time off work to look after her, but it’s scary. The fundraiser is something I’d been wanting to do for a while, to try and raise money for Dr Berg’s research department and Behcetaposs UK as well. Without Dr Berg’s diagnosis in November , Christmas  would have been Abbey’s last. After receiving her diagnosis Abbey was placed on chemotherapy and steroid treatments to prevent the inflammation and will need heart surgery on a mm split which is leaking fluid. The -year-old hopes to be a mum one day and in an attempt to prevent the disease affecting her fertility she is having injections in an attempt to save her eggs. She added: I didn’t realise how serious it was, which was a good thing, but also when they came in to say I had to start chemotherapy and might not be able to have children, it was quite scary. I just thought I had a kidney infection but then they started talking about heart surgery and all this, it’s still strange now.  If I didn’t go in, they thought I was going to die, so it’s a good thing that I got a diagnosis. I’m not religious or anything like that but I do think someone was looking out for me, to go in with a kidney infection and come out with this. I had to leave my job because they said I couldn’t work for  weeks, which is almost a whole year, what was I supposed to do  I think also having an additional barrier of maybe not having children, I meant to be in the prime of my le. She admitted to feeling relieved to know the reason for her symptoms. Abbey added: To finally know what was causing my symptoms, I didn’t want to be in pain all the time, it was such a nice feeling to know that I wasn’t making it up. It was a relief, but it’s a shame that the treatment is so intense. It is for le and it is intense. I struggle to even walk my dog because of my chest pain. I had to get an ambulance last week because I honestly thought my aneurysm had ruptured, and I’ve never been so scared in my le. I really thought that it had ruptured and I was  and dead. It was so scary. Behcetaposs is an incurable form of vasculitis with ying symptoms, and with little research surrounding the illness, it is dficult to receive a diagnosis. title: detainee secret cia detention site
story: Detainee at secret CIA detention site was used as living prop for torture techniquesAmmar Al-Baluchi - a Pakistani   suspect still being held at Guantanamo Bay - was routinely and repeatedly tortured by CIA agents while at a secret facility north of Kabul, Afghanistan known as "Cobalt" or "the darkness" to prisoners, declassied documents have revealed  terror suspect Ammar Al-Baluchi can be seen on the date of his arrest in  Image: APByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A detainee at a CIA black site was left with permanent brain damage after agents used him as a living doll to teach trainee interrogators how to torture, declassied documents have revealed.Ammar Al-Baluchi - a Pakistani   suspect still being held at Guantanamo Bay - was routinely and repeatedly tortured by CIA agents while at a secret facility north of Kabul, Afghanistan known as Cobalt. Details of the methods used on Baluchi - which date back to  - were revealed in documents declassied on Thursday. The report shows that the CIA went well beyond their usual techniques in Baluchiaposs case, and would strip him naked with trainees queuing up to smash his head into a wall. . Officers at the site - known as the Salt Pit and dubbed the darkness by prisoners - tested torture methods without approval from chiefs at the intelligence agency, the documents show. Baluchi remains in custody at the CIAaposs infamous Guantanamo Bay site and is one of five set to face a military court for his alleged involvement in financing the   terrorism plot.  The case itself has been on hold for over  years because lawyers have argued the testimony gathered under torture should not be allowed in court. The report is largely redacted, but there are several passages detailing the type of abuse he was subjected to. Officers at Cobalt, where prisoners were so broken they are said to have voluntarily put themselves on the water-boarding rack, used Baluchi as a living doll to demonstrate unapproved torture techniques to other agents.  The report details how officers used a technique known as Wailing to terrorise Baluchi. He would be naked when interrogators-in-training would line up to repeatedly slam his head into a wall made of plywood while he was restrained with a towel.The report explains: “The interrogators would grab the ends of the towel in front of and below the detainee’s face and shove [Mr Baluchi] backwards into the wall, never letting go of the towel.Baluchi has spoken before about his ordeal, with it only now being officially confirmed in the CIAaposs declassied papers. The horrors were made public as part of a legal challenge for Baluchi to be checked over by an independent physician.CAGE, an NGO campaigning for rule of law and end to the injustices of the War on Terror published an interview with the suspect on their website. In it, Baluchi said: “After US government agents shaved my head, they smashed my head against the wall repeatedly. It continued until I lost count at each session. “As my head was being hit each time I would see sparks of lights in my eyes. As the intensity of the sparks were increasing as a result of repeated hitting. All of a sudden I felt a strong jolt of electricity in my head then I couldn’t see anything and everything went dark and I passed out.”  “The US government had both my hands tied together by tight handcuffs for about  days straight,” he added. “They had to cut the handcuffs by bolt cutters because the handcuffs got so rusted that wouldn’t open with keys.” Baluchi was  in  when he was taken from Karachi in Pakistan and into US custody in what his lawyers claim was an extra-judicial arrest. The black site where the torture took place has reportedly been destroyed. story: Real-le Up house owner forced developers to build around home despite £, offerEdith Macefield, , bought her Seattle, Washington home in  and has refused to leave the farmhouse because she did not want the stress - her story warmed the hearts of many in its similarity to the  Disney film UpEdith Macefield refused to move from the -year-old farmhouse despite pleas from from the property developersByMonica CharsleyNews ReporterSamantha MordiHannah Mackenzie Wood:,  Mar |commentsA pensioner who had lived in her home for over  years, turned down a multimillion-pound offer to move - forcing developers to build a mall around it. Edith Macefield became close friends with the property developers during their long negotiations, despite her stubborn stance. The -year-old who bought the home in  with her mother, refused to leave the tiny -year-old farmhouse as she did not want the stress of moving.The property is widely believed to be the inspiration for the Disney film, Up, The Daily Record reports.She even rejected a m [£.] offer for the home in Seattle, Washington, with her story making national headlines back in . Despite the property not being worth much itself, developers first offered the pensioner , [ £,.] before increasing it to  million.  But the le-changing sum didnapost sway Macefieldaposs mind, with her friend stating that although she didnapost object to the development, she didnapost want to have to go through the stress of moving. Barry Martin, who was the construction manager for the major build, became good friends with her and helped her with favours such as making her meals and giving her a lt to appointments. The pair became so close that Macefield left the house to Marin when she passed away in . Unfortunately, Martin had to sell the property when he became unemployed during an economic downturn. However, the pensioner gave him her blessing to sell before she died. He said: “She told me to hold out until I got my price. I sold it for , [£,.], Despite reports that suggest Macefieldaposs story inspired the  movie Up, it was later revealed that the production began years earlier in . However, Disney did use the house to premiere the movie in Seattle by decorating the front of the house with balloons. story: I named my dog in honour of my late mum - but my family say its disrespectfulThe -year-old woman doesnt understand why her family are so against her dogs name - saying she was only trying to honour her late mums memory when adopting an animal in needShe named her rescue dog Penelope Image: GettyByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsDeciding on a dogaposs name isnapost always as easy as it sounds as there are so many options to choose from. While some owners seek inspiration from their favourite books, television shows and movies, others opt for a name with a more apospersonal meaningapos behind it.But one dog owner has begun to question whether she was in the wrong after naming her dog in honour of her late mum. title: mysterious angelic presence captured floating
story: Mysterious angelic presence captured floating above UK town in eerie videoMatthew Gowans, , filmed the eerie UFO as it hung over Prestwick in Ayrshire and said he had eyes on it for a few secondsA man has captured a strange UFO hanging over houses in Ayrshire Image: Credit: Pen News Matthew GowansByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMysterious footage captures a “humanoid, angelic” presence hanging over the streets of a Scottish city.The eerie stillness of the UFO as it hung over Prestwick, Ayrshire, spurred Matthew Gowans, , to record what he was seeing.“I was starting work for the day and it caught my eye,” he said. “I think,it had been moving, I wouldn’t have paid it much mind. I probably would’ve assumed it was just a balloon or something. “But the fact that it appeared to be completely still was what prompted me to record it.”He continued: “I still have no idea what it could’ve been. “If you use your imagination a bit, it almost appears humanoid, maybe even angelic. I wish I had a phone with a really good zoom to be honest. “I’d be interested to hear what an expert would have to say. “Realistically, it’s probably a trick of the light, but it’s like nothing I’ve ever seen before.” Sharing his footage online, Matthew soon discovered that he wasn’t alone in what he saw. “The most intriguing responses were the couple of people who claimed to have seen something very similar,” he said. “One person said they’d seen it that very same morning where in Scotland.” Mr Gowans kept his eyes on the mysterious presence for a couple of minutes, before looking away for a few seconds to check some of the footage he’d recorded. By the time he’d lted his eyes again, it was gone. “I’m disappointed I didn’t keep an eye on it for longer,” he said. And while some viewers have offered totally ordinary explanations for what he saw, its true nature remains a mystery.  Matthew said: “There were some definitive claims made about it, but the range of those claims proves it’s not cut and dry.“One person said it’s obviously a cloud, one person said it’s obviously a weather balloon, one person said it’s obviously a plane, and so forth.“Personally I don’t think it’s any of those things.” And when it comes to the extraterrestrial, Mr Gowans takes a nuanced view. He said: “Certainly there’s other intelligent le in space. People that believe otherwise sort of baffle me. I mean, the sheer size of the universe… “But, given that sheer size, I think the chances that aliens have made it all the way to Earth – or even been made aware of us – are slim. “There’s so many sightings these days, though, and that NASA investigation a while back was interesting – so many Navy pilots have recounted seemingly credible encounters.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NasaUFOs" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: People joke theyd rather stay thirsty after seeing odd demand on coffee cupsPeople have been left baffled by the odd demand on a range of disposable coffee cups shared online - with some saying theyd rather stay thirsty than get involvedThe cups sparked the fear of networking in those onlineImage: Getty Images WestendByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |commentsAs anyone with a corporate job will know, thereaposs nothing more uncomfortable than being forced to socialise with people you barely know as part of a business event.And one woman on Twitter has sparked the fear of networking in thousands of people after she shared a picture of a stack of multi-coloured disposable coffee cups that were seemingly used at a work conference - as they were specically designed to encourage communication between attendees. Jordan Mapes posted the picture of the cups online, where they sat alongside a note that explained how people could choose the cup that was right for them.The cups each had words printed on the front including strategy, articial intelligence, innovation, and leadership, and attendees were told to pick a cup based on what they wanted to talk to others about. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Alongside the cups, a note read: Pick a cup based on what you would like to discuss most. This will help everyone to network with like-minded people.Jordan, who posts on Twitter under the username @jordanmapes, then kicked off a debate around the idea of the cups, as she said she would simply not drink coffeeit meant she had to socialise at the same time.Many others took a similar stance, with thousands replying to the tweet to share their distaste for mingling at business meetings - especially when itaposs forced through the use of coffee cups. One person said: I would drink it from my cupped hands rather than go through this torture.  While another added: Nightmares from my days in marketing. And a third said: Strategy is literally my job and even I wouldnapost want this. Others jokingly shared what they would write on their own cups instead, with answers including dinosaurs, Fight Club, and memes. Someone tweeted: This is why I carry a Sharpie with me at all times. Iaposd have to put aposLeave me the f**k aloneapos. As someone  added: Just bring a sharpie with you, cross out whatever it says on your preferred colour of cup, and write aposcatsapos instead. But some were in favour of the idea, as one person pointed out the cups could actually be useful in the right setting, providing everyone involved actually wants to socialise. They said: I actually kinda like the idea, assuming that this is happening at some kind of conference or event where people came specically to discuss this kind of thing, as opposed to the cups being handed out to random people in the street or something. And another agreed, writing: This is dumb but % a genius event idea. Theyaposre always looking for ways to start conversations. story: Woman in stitches after £ Too Good To Go bag arrives with  broccolisRachel Jenkins has been left laughing after she bought a Too Good To Go bag from Morrisons for £ - but was left with  broccolis that she had no idea how to useRachel was baffled when she opened up her £ bag Image: Caters News AgencyByZahna EklundAudience writerCally Brooks:,  Mar |commentsWeaposd all love to save a little more money on our shopping and cut down on food waste in the process, and thanks to Too Good To Go, doing both couldnapost be simpler.The app allows shops and restaurants to sign up to sell food products that would otherwise be thrown away at a hugely discounted price, with only one catch to the customer - you donapost know whataposs inside your bag until you pick it up. And for Rachel Jenkins, her decision to try out the £ bags offered on the app by Morrisons came with a hilarious surprise, as she opened her bag to find no less than  broccolis. Rachel, , from West London, said she chose to give the app a go after seeing it advertised online but was left bemused when instead of the iety of fruit, vegetables, meat, deli, cheese, and dairy that are on offer in the mystery bags, she instead got lumped with almost three dozen of the same green veg. The carer purchased the bag for £. on February  and picked it up later that evening, where she opened it to find  packets of double broccoli, along with one box of grapes, strawberries, and parsley. Rachel explained: I was shocked at how much broccoli they had given me!  Itaposs luck of the draw what youaposre given and I knew that so I wasnapost expecting too much but definitely didnapost think Iaposd received so much broccoli. I have given some to neighbours, friends, and family but am keeping the rest in the freezer for when I get round to eating it.And although she was disappointed with her first experience with the Too Good To Go bags, Rachel is more than keen to try her luck with another order.She added: Even though I was a bit disappointed, I definitely would purchase again because Iaposm intrigued as to what I could get next. Defence has explained why Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has stalled and is failing so far.In the latest intelligence update on the ongoing invasion of Ukraine, they highlighted a number of the problems that Putin’s forces had run into. Challenges like the terrain, and transport issues have severely hampered Moscow’s ability to advance across what is the biggest European country by landmass. On top of that, an inability to secure control of the sky has “drastically limited” their ability to utilise jets and limited their options further. On top of that, the military acumen of the Ukrainian forces and the tactics they have used have exploited Russian weakness and inflicted “heavy losses” on Putin’s invading forces.Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here In a statement released on Twitter, they said: “Russian forces are struggling to overcome the challenges posed by Ukraine’s terrain.“They have remained largely tied to Ukraine’s road network and have demonstrated a reluctance to conduct off-road manoeuvres.“The destruction of bridges by Ukrainian forces has also played a key role in stalling Russia ’s advance.“Russia’s continued failure to gain control of the air has drastically limited their ability to effectively use air manoeuvres, further limiting their options.  “The tactics of the Ukrainian Armed Forces have adeptly exploited Russia’s lack of manoeuvre, frustrating the Russian advance and inflicting heavy losses on invading forces.” This comes as one of Putinaposs closest allies has admitted Russiaaposs invasion of Ukraine have not gone to plan. Viktor Zolotov, chief of Russiaaposs national guard and apart of Putinaposs security council, said progress of the invasion had been slower than expected. He said: I would like to say that yes, not everything is going as fast as we would like, Zolotov said in comments posted on the National Guardaposs website. But we are going towards our goal step by step and victory will be for us.  Zolotov has been at Putinaposs side since before the turn of the century and has spent the last  years in charge of his personal security. His comments, made at a church service led by Orthodox Patriarch Kirill on Sunday, have reflected reports from Western intelligence and mark a departure from official Kremlin lines so far. This comes as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine comes to the end of its third week. In that time, Russia has lost four major generals and nearly a dozen high-ranking officers. It has sustained heavier casualties than Ukraine, and lost more tanks than Germany has in its army.  It was reported, Russia initially planned a ‘lightning invasion’ that would have seen Putin’s forces sweep the country and take Kyiv in a matter of days. However, now the Kremlin finds itself in protracted warfare against Ukraine’s forces and negotiating with the government it hoped to oust. Russia’s invasion has reportedly been plagued with issues such as low morale and supply issues. A number of videos have circulated on social media, showing Russian vehicles running out of fuel. Russia has maintained the invasion is going to plan, but reports from US intelligence officials have said they have been asking China for military equipment since the beginning of the invasion.  After initial failures to conquer Ukraineaposs cities, Russia has turned to relentless shelling and bombing of civilian targets. The deadly invasion has led to thousands of deaths and has led to over three million refugees having fled from their homes since February . The United Nations High Commission for Refugees said, that as of March , ,, Ukrainians had left their homes.  Over half of these, ,,, have entered into Poland, the main destination of refugees so far, but it is not known how many intend to stay here, or move in to other countries. Despite its size, Moldova has taken in , people, the most per capita of any nation. Over , Ukrainians, largely from the country’s eastern regions, have fled into Russia. news world-news real-story-behind-touching-viral-"Pulya the Ukrainian dog whose photo went viralByJilly BeattieLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The image of a dog being carried to the Polish border from Ukraine on a manaposs shoulders went viral when it was shared online - and now the real story behind it has been revealed.Capturing the hearts of many, the photo shows a man carrying six stoneaposs worth of Pulya, the familyaposs dog, down a frosty road. The photo taken by Alisa Teptiuk, , travelled the internet leaving behind many questions and concerns. Belfast Live has exclusively shared the real story behind that incredible image, taken on a mobile phone by an exhausted we and mum as her family fled Ukraine for their lives.We tracked down Alisa to her temporary home in Poland where she explained how the snap of her beloved dog riding on her husbandaposs shoulder became world famous in an instant.Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News BulletinhereUntil last month Alisa and husband Dmytro had lived in Kyiv with their two daughters and their German Shepherd. Le was settled and happy, the children were at school, the dog spent her days between walks and snoozes and the family’s grandparents doted on everyone. Now Alisa, her children and their dog are in exile in Warsaw where they are safe and close to her mother and sister. But Alisa’s beloved father is dead, still in a morgue in Kyiv awaiting burial, and her husband is back in Ukraine trying to take care of his parents and defend their home. With the Russian bombardment now hitting their hometown hard, Alisa is living in abject fear while trying to keep her feelings under wraps in front of her daughters - but she has one steady comfort, her dog Pulya.Follow all the latest updates from Ukraine in our live blogAlisa told DogsLive : “She is a comfort to all of us. She’s old but always the same, loving and gentle. We couldn’t leave her behind. Pulya is family. She is a German Shepherd aged  and a half, she is old and grey after a letime with us. We bought her on the first day of my maternity leave when she was almost four months old.“That day I began to train with her. She has been through the happiest and saddest moments of le with us. She understands us and loves us and we love her very much and will do everything to look after her and keep her safe. No one could convince us that Pulya could be left behind. It was not possible, we didn’t even think about it.Today she is alive and doing well, she stands as a symbol of love, devotion, determination, she represents our family, the lives we had, the lives weaposve left behind. Pulya is our one constant in all of this madness.”Pulya, whose name translates from Ukrainian to English as Bullet, travelled with her family of nine plus Alisa’s mother’s dog Kolt, aged four, in a small car for  miles heading to the safety of Poland.Alisa said: “It was my idea to go to the border but it was very painful to leave our home. My father died unexpectedly on February . He was just  and Dmytro and I tried everything to have him buried, but he’s still in the morgue because war broke out on February , the day after he died. “People were leaving Kyiv while my husband Dmytro and I were trying to sort out funeral documents at places all over the city in order to bury Dad. “We went from morgue to funeral agency to prosecutor’s office to registry office to morgue to funeral agency. The sirens were sounding all over the place and tanks were driving around the city. We had collected almost all the documents, booked a restaurant for a commemoration service and then discovered the registry office had been evacuated which left us without the one final document we needed.“In the end the crematorium refused to accept anyone. So my poor dad is still in the morgue. I hope that when I come back he’ll still be there. I will give him the best funeral I can. “It was heartbreaking but we had to go. We packed five adults, four children and our two dogs into a Peugeot  car and we drove out of Kyiv. We filled every bit of space, my mother, myself and my sister, our two husbands, the four children and two big dogs Pulya and Kolt. We drove for  hours to a village about  miles from Kyiv and then we stopped.” As the family drove on towards Poland the traffic grew heavier, and then they hit gridlock and faced the possibility of a three to five day journey inching to the border. Alisa said they felt like sitting ducks. Alisa explained: “We decided to leave the village later shortly after we arrived because it was just too dangerous to sit still, even there. As we got closer to the border there were a lot of cars queuing and we were told it would take the next three, or may five days to get to the border by car. We didnapost want to sit in a queue without shelter, open to the air, open to attack.  “So we decided to walk the last  miles. We left at am. It was minus seven degrees. It was a hard trip around mountains and rivers. Our kids were crying because it was so cold. I wanted to cry too, I could feel the tears travelling to my eyes but I couldn’t allow myself to cry, I couldn’t give up. It had been my idea to go to the border, we were almost there and we just had to keep going.” It was during that last stretch walking on the road that Alisa took the now famous photo of Pulya. She said: “Pulya was fantastic. She walked a lot of the way but she’s old and she needed to stop to rest and then she struggled to get back on her feet and she was getting slower and more tired.  “I stopped cars to beg for help but everyone refused. They told us to leave the dogs, to save our family. They didn’t understand, our dogs are our family too, Pulya comes too. “Pulya is no less family than anyone . She has been through everything with us, good times, happy days, hard times, sadness and now war and exile. And Kolt is the same. He’s my mum’s dog and all she has left of her former le, he is her comfort. “So we walked on and when Pulya got tired Dmytro lted her onto his shoulder and he carried her. I took a photo without thinking about it too much. I suppose I just wanted to capture the moment. But now I know how special it is. It shows the world our love and devotion. Weaposre just an ordinary family who love each other. Pulya was  kg when we started the walk. Sheaposs  kilos now. When she could walk no more Dmytro lted her. She was so calm. I think she understood we needed to keep moving and she needed to let us help her.Sheaposs a beautul dog. She reacted calmly to being lted, she didn’t struggle. You have to remember she knows we’re her family too and she completely trusts us. “We made it to the border, all  of the family including the dogs and we rested for a few hours. We could see rows of red tents and a big crowd. A woman asked me to take her -year-old daughter - someone was waiting for her in Poland. I agreed of course. “The decision to leave our home and the journey to Poland was hard physically and psychologically and we could see a lot of people around us needing help and medicine. “We rested in a tent for about seven hours together, the dogs and the five children. We were exhausted, sad and our feet were wet but we’d made it. We were safe.Before the war Alisa, , worked as a computer specialist for a German company helping develop Python, one of the worldaposs most popular programming languages that has been used to create everything from Netflix ’s recommendation algorithm to the software that controls self-driving cars. Her husband Dmytro, , worked as a fibre optic network installation engineer and was just about to start new high level qualications.Today work is just a memory for the couple and they donapost know what the future holds living more than  miles apart despite the success of their journey together to exile. Stepping onto Polish soil heralded a bittersweet victory because just hours later Dmytro and his brother-in-law had to turn around and make their way back to Ukraine. Alisa said: “We took our first steps into Poland and showed our passes and that was when I realised that weaposd be OK, that we were in a safe place. For a moment everything felt fine. “Our dogs passed their health checks and were allowed to come in with us but my husband and brother-in-law couldn’t cross the border because of their age and the mobilisation order. They had to go back home. “Right now I’m in limbo. I want my husband here with us but for now I must find a safe place to stay with my children. Weaposve not decided whether to stay here in Poland or go to Germany like many of my work colleagues. “It was so hard to leave my home, to leave Ukraine. First I lost my dad, and now I’ve left my husband there. Dmytro is such a big part of me, my best friend, companion, adviser. Our deep love is what gives me strength now. “Everything had to be left in Kyiv, our home, our gadgets, everything, but these are just things. The only important things I left behind in Ukraine are my dad’s body and my husband and I am very worried about him, constantly thinking about him.
